item.title: FairEmail announcement to Stop Developing
item.description: Qadarallah, I’m really sorry to FairEmail, because they have stopped providing their services due to Google falsely flagged FairEmail as spyware without a reasonable opportunity to appeal, as stated on its website. The mail client has been irreplaceable on Android for me, come to an end. Though, you can still use their app without their service using an open standard. Article posts: https://faircode.eu/faq.html

item.title: Get Rid of Public DNS (nsd4) is not running (port 53). on Mail-in-a-Box
item.description: It’s really annoying to see cross marks on status checks on Mail-in-a-Box Solution: sudo sysctl -w net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6=0 sudo sysctl -w net.ipv6.conf.default.disable_ipv6=0 sudo service nsd start

item.title: Hardening Firefox using Arkenfox user.js
item.description: You can read the Arkenfox official wiki based on your threat model and create the user-overrides.js file / download or copy here user-overrides.js Download the official release from here or use git clone from https://github.com/arkenfox/user.js Locate your Mozilla Firefox profile, and open terminal Linux or MacOS: Copy the prefsCleaner.sh, updater.sh and user.js file from the extracted zip into your Firefox profile, as well as your user-overrides.js file. On your terminal inside your Firefox profile folder.

item.title: Using DNF on Fedora Sliverblue
item.description: Steps to use DNF command like a regular Fedora on Silverblue using aliases cat >> ~/.bashrc << EOF alias sudo="sudo " alias dnf="bash -c '#skip_sudo'; toolbox -y create 2>/dev/null; toolbox run sudo dnf" EOF

item.title: Free Up RAM on Debian or Ubuntu
item.description: free -h && sudo sysctl -w vm.drop_caches=3 && sudo sync && echo 3 | sudo tee /proc/sys/vm/drop_caches && free -h

item.title: Why Self-hosting
item.description: The concept in which we host our own applications, data, and more. Taking away the “unknown” factor in how our data is managed and stored, this provides those with the willingness to learn and the mind to do so to take control of our data without losing the functionality of services we otherwise use frequently. That makes us much aware about our own privacy.

item.title: Writefreely with Docker Compose
item.description: Download the stable release as mentioned on Writefreely using wget command sudo wget https://github.com/writefreely/writefreely/releases/download/v0.13.1/writefreely_0.13.1_linux_amd64.tar.gz sudo tar -zxvf writefreely_0.13.1_linux_amd64.tar.gz Generate config.ini before generating keys cd writefreely sudo ./writefreely --config My current setup is, you can configure as you like Server setup Production, behind reverse proxy Database setup SQLite Generate keys sudo ./writefreely --gen-keys Locate keys directory and make it a writeable file cd keys sudo chmod 777 *keys.file* Create a docker-compose.
